title: Time & Touch
description: Explore how you share time and physical affection.

questions.text: What type of quality time together do I value most?

therapeutic.rationale: Quality time means different things to different people. Activity-lovers connect through doing; conversationalists bond through talking; novelty-seekers need new experiences; relaxers need low-pressure time. A relationship needs enough of each partner's preferred quality time to feel connected.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different quality time preferences mean you feel connected at different moments. The activity-lover may feel bored just sitting; the relaxer may feel exhausted by constant activity. Balance both styles of togetherness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared quality time preferences mean you'll naturally create connection through the same activities. You experience togetherness the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most connected during time together? What kind of time together leaves you feeling most filled up?

questions.text: How much physical affection do I prefer in daily life?
choices: Minimal during day, more at intimate times
Light but consistent throughout the day

therapeutic.rationale: Physical affection needs vary widely and aren't indicators of love depth. High-touch people feel connected through constant contact; moderate-touch people need some physical connection; context-dependent touchers separate daily and intimate; light-but-consistent touchers prefer ongoing small touches. Touch mismatches cause significant relationship distress.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different touch needs create one of the most challenging relationship mismatches. The high-touch person may feel rejected by the lower-touch partner; the lower-touch person may feel smothered. Negotiate rather than personalize touch differences.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared touch preferences make physical connection effortless. You'll naturally give and want the same amount of affection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much physical affection do you want in daily life? Is there a mismatch with your partner? How do you navigate it?

questions.text: What's my ideal balance of together time vs. alone time?
choices: Most of my free time with you
Daily connection with some solo time

therapeutic.rationale: Togetherness needs reflect introversion/extroversion and attachment style. High-togetherness people recharge through connection; balanced people need both; space-needers require solitude to function. Partners with different togetherness needs must negotiate rather than assume their need is 'right.'
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different togetherness needs are extremely common and require explicit negotiation. The high-togetherness partner may feel rejected by the space-needer's need for solitude; the space-needer may feel suffocated by constant togetherness. Neither is wrongâ€”both needs are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared togetherness needs make relationship rhythms natural. You'll both want to be together (or apart) at the same times.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much time together versus alone do you ideally need? Does your relationship provide this balance? What adjustments would help?

questions.text: How do I prefer to maintain intimacy in our relationship?

therapeutic.rationale: Intimacy maintenance differs significantly between people. Touch-maintainers need physical connection; conversation-maintainers need emotional depth; experience-maintainers need shared activities; acts-of-love maintainers need daily caring. Knowing how your partner maintains intimacy helps you contribute to ongoing closeness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different intimacy maintenance styles can lead to feeling disconnected despite both partners' efforts. The touch-maintainer may feel distant when the conversation-maintainer offers talks instead of cuddles. Feed intimacy in your partner's way.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared intimacy maintenance means you'll keep closeness alive through the same activities. You'll both feel the relationship being nurtured.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What maintains intimacy for you? When does closeness fade? What activities or behaviors bring it back?

questions.text: What makes me feel most connected during physical intimacy?

therapeutic.rationale: Physical intimacy serves different emotional functions for different people. Presence-seekers need to feel their partner's full attention; verbal-seekers need affirmation during intimacy; desire-seekers need to feel wanted; afterglow-seekers treasure post-intimacy closeness. Understanding what makes intimacy connecting for your partner deepens the experience.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different connection points during intimacy can be accommodated once known. The eye-contact seeker can ask for more presence; the verbal-seeker can request affirmation. Share what makes intimacy feel most connecting.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared connection points mean intimacy will naturally feel bonding in the same ways. You'll both experience the same moments as peak connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes physical intimacy feel most connecting for you? Have you shared this with your partner? What would deepen your experience?
